title: What the Saudi Attacks Mean for Energy Investors
text:
Soon after the attacks on Saudi Arabia’s oil infrastructure last Saturday, investors and analysts were calling it a black-swan event—the kind of unexpected shock that shakes markets and forces changes to investing models.

Attackers using low-flying drones and cruise missiles knocked out 5.7 million barrels worth of production, or about 60% of what Saudi Arabia currently produces. It was the largest supply disruption in history. On Monday, Brent oil futures shot 15% higher, the most since 2008, and the oil equities most dependent...
description: The initial spike in oil prices after the attacks on Saudi facilities soon faded. But the supply disruption and its aftermath offer valuable lessons to energy investors.
